texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I’m about to tell you the story of one girl.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: A story I tell to every person that comes here.
The briny breeze brushes against my cheek.
In front of the small, seaside cabin.
About 20 people gather every day on the wooden deck overlooking the horizon.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I hope that this story will remain in the memories of many people and be recalled again and again.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I continue to tell this story in the belief that it will one day lead to a miraculous moment.
I slowly open the cover of the thick book in my hand.
It never rains here.
Pleasant sunlight envelops us every day.
Every page of my book was uniformly tanned and tired from absorbing the moisture of the sea breeze.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: We all have our own “individuality.”

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Its true nature is only collection of memories each of us makes throughout our lives.
Next page.
I remember every word of what is written here.
Even so, I keep it close at hand because the same touch every day gives me a little peace of mind.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: When it’s time to make a judgment, we use our past experiences as guidelines to lead us.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: And those judgments lead to the actions we take. That’s why...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Our past experiences—our memories inform our words and deeds.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: We judge a person's character by looking at their behavior.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: In other words, we indirectly recognize the accumulation of memories of the other person as individuality.
I looked up.
The eyes of the gathered people are directed at me.
I closed my eyes.
I always close my eyes before starting this story.
I could hear the waves.
I take a deep breath and take in the scent of the calm tides.
And behind my closed eyes, a girl comes into view.
She's here today too.
She's always there, inside of me.
I opened my eyes slowly.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: But after all, we can only see the world the way we want to see it.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: No matter how hard we try, we can't correct the distortion of our perception.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Is the world I see the same as the world you see—I can't even judge that.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Still, this world is formed from the accumulation of individual common recognition.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The very existence of this world is a miracle.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: There were many hardships and long anguish to get here... and there were great sacrifices.
I turn my face to a boy sitting in the front row.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: You can see the sea right behind me, can you?
I say, looking straight into his eyes.
The boy gives me a small, sheepish nod.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Do you think it's beautiful?
Again, he nods.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: That clear blue sea that blurs in the horizon and melts into the sky. What wills those waves is the common ideals of everyone in this world.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The sea that everyone around the world dreams about... That is what you’re seeing right now. That’s why it’s so beautiful.
The boys stares at me for a moment before nodding again.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I decided to define myself as someone who would continue to tell this story.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: I want to tell you the story of the one that taught me what life is.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: The one who taught me that I can decide for myself even while bound by other’s perception.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: A girl.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: Her name was Yonagi.

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: What I’m about to tell you is...

texts.name: Kaito
texts.text: ...the story of the girl who dreamed the world.
